results.title: Africa: the land and its people. No. 4
results.brief_description: Magazine items: Study of Cape Town, seaport and commercial centre of the Union of South Africa. Discusses and illustrates influence of the Dutch on the life and art of the Cape; shows coastal landmarks and suburbs, Table Mountain, the Twelve Apostles; concludes with scenes from a ballet produced by the Corps de Ballet of the University of Cape Town.

results.title: Africa: the land and its people. No. 3
results.brief_description: Magazine items: Historical survey of the Union of South Africa as reflected in the Union’s architecture, furniture and sculpture - work of seventeenth-century French artist, Louis Michel Thibault. Growing of sisal on plantations in Kenya, Tanganyika and Nyasaland and the manufacture of sisal into string, twine and rope.

results.title: Africa: the land and its people. No. 2
results.brief_description: Magazine items: Fruit and vegetable growing in the Union of South Africa for home use, export and canning. World famous archeologist L’Abbe Breuil at work among the Bushmen, a dwindling tribe of nomadic hunters who have left a history of primitive man in their cave paintings.

results.title: Africa: the land and its people. No. 1
results.brief_description: Magazine items: Johannesburg Art Gallery, home of many works of the seventeenth century Dutch and Flemish schools, the French impressionists and the work of many African artists. Work of the South African Institute for Medical Research in the preparation of snake-bite antidotes manufactured from venom extracted from snakes.

results.title: Africa: physical geography
results.brief_description: Africa - the second largest continent - lies almost entirely within the tropics. It is the only continent found in all four hemispheres, divided by both the Prime Meridian - which separates the eastern and Western Hemispheres, and the Equator - which separates the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. North and south of the Equator, Africa’s symmetrical pattern of landscapes and climates is apparent : there are tropical forests, savannas, semi-deserts, deserts and mountains. Africa has numerous waterfalls, such as Victoria Falls, the longest river in the world - the Nile, and the world’s largest desert - the Sahara. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s Guide included.

results.title: Africa: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Wayne Mitchell and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Provides an overview of the people and the continent of Africa. Notes the different races of people, their history and social conditions that exist today including the system of apartheid. Also looks at the geography of the continent showing diversity between grasslands, desert and tropical areas. Briefly mentions African problems such as housing and education.

results.title: Africa: a new look
results.creator_credit: Sam Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: A comprehensive survey which concentrates on the people of Africa today in all walks of life, and with glimpses of life in the cities, towns and villages. Shows some of the economic and social changes that are taking place throughout the many nations of Africa. An animated map sequence pinpoints deserts, farmland, rivers and major population areas. A final sequence focuses on South Africa and Namibia, where the official racial policies are opposed by Africans throughout the continent. Suitable for lower and middle secondary level.

results.title: Africa untamed
results.brief_description: Documentary examining life and customs in Equatorial Africa. The film follows a boat trip through pygmie country to a pygmie village and shows hunters at work spearing a leopard. The problems of tsi tsi fly and sleeping sickness in big game country are discussed and the behavioural traits of the wild life found in this area, such as giraffes, rhinos and hippos, are examined. Also shows a hunting party in action in elephant country.

results.title: Africa mosaic
results.brief_description: Depicts South Africa as a complex and multi-racial country with a vast diversity of ethnic groups, each with its own language, religion and cultural heritage. Previewing prior to class screening is recommended.

results.title: Africa is my home
results.creator_credit: J. Michael Hagopian and Atlantis Productions
results.brief_description: The life of a Nigerian woman from birth to marriage, as she faces the basic issues of tradition versus progress, Christianity versus Islam, and colonialism versus independence. The strength of family and tribal ties; the happy village life of her childhood; her first awareness of the different religious faiths around her; going to the mission school and being fired by her father’s zeal for independence; growing awareness of political and social problems as she goes to teachers college; her fiance’s graduation from university and his decision to work in the service of his country; their marriage in a Christian church.
